001package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.ycwcm;
002
003import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.FloatColors;
004import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.MathTools;
005import com.github.tommyettinger.ds.support.BitConversion;
006
007import java.util.Random;
008
009/**
010 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int} and packed {@code float} values in the YCwCm color space.
011 */
012public class ColorTools {
013        /**
014         * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, Y (luma or lightness), Cw
015         * (chromatic warmth), Cm (chromatic mildness), and A (alpha or opacity).
016         * Luma should be between 0 and 1, inclusive, with 0 used for very dark colors (almost only black), and 1 used for
017         * very light colors (almost only white). The two chroma values range from 0.0 to 1.0, and there's some aesthetic
018         * value in changing just one chroma value. When warm is high and mild is low, the color is more reddish, when both
019         * are low it is more bluish, when mild is high and warm is low, the color tends to be greenish, and when both are
020         * high it tends to be brown or yellow. When warm and mild are both near 0.5f, the color is closer to gray.  Alpha
021         * is the multiplicative opacity of the color, and acts like RGBA's alpha.
022         * <br>
023         * This method bit-masks the resulting color's byte values, so any values can technically be given to this as luma,
024         * warm, and mild, but they will only be reversible from the returned float color to the original Y, Cw, and Cm
025         * values if the original values were a valid YCwCm color and not an "imaginary color." {@link #fromRGBA(float)}
026         * should always produce a valid YCwCm color.
027         *
028         * @param luma       0f to 1f, luma or Y component of YCwCm, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
029         * @param warm       0f to 1f, "chroma warm" or Cw component of YCwCm, with 1f more red or yellow
030         * @param mild       0f to 1f, "chroma mild" or Cm component of YCwCm, with 1f more green or yellow
031         * @param alpha      0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque 
032         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
033         */
034        public static float ycwcm(float luma, float warm, float mild, float alpha) {
035                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (mild * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
036                                | ((int) (warm * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (luma * 255) & 0xFF));
037        }
038
039        /**
040         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)} to an RGBA8888 int.
041         * This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
042         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
043         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
044         */
045        public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed)
046        {
047                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed), y = (decoded & 0xff),
048                                cw = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xfe),
049                                cm = (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xfe) >> 1);
050                return Math.min(Math.max(y + (cw * 5 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) << 24
051                                | Math.min(Math.max(y - (cw * 3 >> 3) + cm, 0), 0xFF) << 16
052                                | Math.min(Math.max(y - (cw * 3 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) << 8
053                                | (decoded & 0xfe000000) >>> 24 | decoded >>> 31;
054        }
055
056        /**
057         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
058         * to a packed float in RGBA format.
059         * This format of float can be used with the standard SpriteBatch and in some other places in libGDX.
060         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
061         * @return a packed float color as RGBA
062         */
063        public static float toRGBA(final float packed)
064        {
065                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed), y = (decoded & 0xff),
066                                cw = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xfe),
067                                cm = (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xfe) >> 1);
068                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(Math.min(Math.max(y + (cw * 5 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF)
069                                | Math.min(Math.max(y - (cw * 3 >> 3) + cm, 0), 0xFF) << 8
070                                | Math.min(Math.max(y - (cw * 3 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) << 16
071                                | (decoded & 0xfe000000));
072        }
073
074        /**
075         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the YCwCm this uses.
076         * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
077         * @return a packed float as YCwCm, which this class can use
078         */
079        public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
080                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((rgba >>> 24) * 3 + (rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 4 + (rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) >> 3)
081                                | (0xFF + (rgba >>> 24) - (rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) & 0x1FE) << 7
082                                | (0xFF + (rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) - (rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) & 0x1FE) << 15
083                                | (rgba & 0xFE) << 24);
084        }
085
086        /**
087         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 packed float and converts to a packed float in the YCwCm this uses.
088         * @param packed a packed float in RGBA8888 format, with A in the MSB and R in the LSB
089         * @return a packed float as YCwCm, which this class can use
090         */
091        public static float fromRGBA(final float packed) {
092                final int rgba = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
093                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((rgba & 0xFF) * 3 + (rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 4 + (rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) >> 3)
094                                | (0xFF + (rgba & 0xFF) - (rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) & 0x1FE) << 7
095                                | (0xFF + (rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) - (rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) & 0x1FE) << 15
096                                | (rgba >>> 24 & 0xFE) << 24);
097        }
098
099        /**
100         * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the YCwCm this uses.
101         * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
102         * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
103         * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
104         * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
105         * @return a packed float as YCwCm, which this class can use
106         */
107        public static float fromRGBA(final float r, final float g, final float b, final float a) {
108                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((int) (255 * (r * 0x3p-3f + g * 0x4p-3f + b * 0x1p-3f)) & 0xFF
109                                                | (int)((r - b + 1f) * 127.5f) << 8 & 0xFF00
110                                                | (int)((g - b + 1f) * 127.5f) << 16 & 0xFF0000
111                                                | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
112        }
113
114        /**
115         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
116         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
117         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
118         */
119        public static int redInt(final float encoded)
120        {
121                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
122                return (decoded & 0xff) + (((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xfe) * 5 >>> 4) - (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xfe) >>> 2);
123        }
124
125        /**
126         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
127         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
128         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
129         */
130        public static int greenInt(final float encoded)
131        {
132                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
133                return (decoded & 0xff) - (((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xfe) * 3 >> 4) + (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xfe) >> 2);
134        }
135
136        /**
137         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
138         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
139         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
140         */
141        public static int blueInt(final float encoded)
142        {
143                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
144                return (decoded & 0xff) - (((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xfe) * 3 >> 4) - (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xfe) >> 2);
145        }
146
147        /**
148         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
149         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
150         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
151         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
152         */
153        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded)
154        {
155                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
156        }
157
158        /**
159         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
160         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
161         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
162         */
163        public static float red(final float encoded)
164        {
165                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
166                return Math.min(Math.max((decoded & 0xff) * 0x1.010102p-8f + ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0x1.414142p-9f) - ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * 0x1.010102p-9f, 0f), 1f);
167        }
168
169        /**
170         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
171         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
172         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
173         */
174        public static float green(final float encoded)
175        {
176                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
177                return Math.min(Math.max((decoded & 0xff) * 0x1.010102p-8f - (((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * 0x1.818184p-10f) + ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * 0x1.010102p-9f, 0f), 1f);
178        }
179
180        /**
181         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
182         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
183         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
184         */
185        public static float blue(final float encoded)
186        {
187                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
188                return Math.min(Math.max((decoded & 0xff) * 0x1.010102p-8f - (((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * 0x1.818184p-10f) - ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * 0x1.010102p-9f, 0f), 1f);
189        }
190
191        /**
192         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
193         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
194         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
195         */
196        public static float alpha(final float encoded)
197        {
198                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0.003937008f;
199        }
200
201
202        /**
203         * Gets a color as a YCwCm packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
204         * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
205         * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
206         * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
207         * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
208         * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
209         * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
210         * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
211         *
212         * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
213         * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
214         * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
215         * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
216         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
217         */
218        public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
219                if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
220                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
221                } else {
222                        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
223                }
224        }
225
226        /**
227         * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
228         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
229         * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
230         */
231        public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
232                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded), lu = (decoded & 0xff),
233                                cw = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xfe),
234                                cm = (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xfe) >> 1);
235                final float r = Math.min(Math.max(lu + (cw * 5 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
236                final float g = Math.min(Math.max(lu - (cw * 3 >> 3) + cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
237                final float b =  Math.min(Math.max(lu - (cw * 3 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
238                float x, y, w;
239                if(g < b) {
240                        x = b;
241                        y = g;
242                }
243                else {
244                        x = g;
245                        y = b;
246                }
247                if(r < x) {
248                        w = r;
249                }
250                else {
251                        w = x;
252                        x = r;
253                }
254                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
255                float li = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
256                return (x - li) / (Math.min(li, 1f - li) + 1e-10f);
257        }
258
259        public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
260                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded), lu = (decoded & 0xff),
261                                cw = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xfe),
262                                cm = (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xfe) >> 1);
263                final float r = Math.min(Math.max(lu + (cw * 5 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
264                final float g = Math.min(Math.max(lu - (cw * 3 >> 3) + cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
265                final float b =  Math.min(Math.max(lu - (cw * 3 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
266                float x, y, w;
267                if(g < b) {
268                        x = b;
269                        y = g;
270                }
271                else {
272                        x = g;
273                        y = b;
274                }
275                if(r < x) {
276                        w = r;
277                }
278                else {
279                        w = x;
280                        x = r;
281                }
282                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
283                return x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
284        }
285
286        /**
287         * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
288         * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
289         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
290         * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
291         * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
292         */
293        public static float hue(final float encoded) {
294                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded), lu = (decoded & 0xff),
295                                cw = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xfe),
296                                cm = (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xfe) >> 1);
297                final float r = Math.min(Math.max(lu + (cw * 5 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
298                final float g = Math.min(Math.max(lu - (cw * 3 >> 3) + cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
299                final float b =  Math.min(Math.max(lu - (cw * 3 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
300                float x, y, z, w;
301                if(g < b) {
302                        x = b;
303                        y = g;
304                        z = -1f;
305                        w = 2f / 3f;
306                }
307                else {
308                        x = g;
309                        y = b;
310                        z = 0f;
311                        w = -1f / 3f;
312                }
313                if(r < x) {
314                        z = w;
315                        w = r;
316                }
317                else {
318                        w = x;
319                        x = r;
320                }
321                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
322                return Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
323        }
324
325        /**
326         * The "luma" of the given packed float in YCwCm format, which is like its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
327         * 1.0f . YCwCm is useful for modifications to colors:
328         * <ul>
329         *     <li>You can get a grayscale version of a color by setting Cw and Cm to 0.5,</li>
330         *     <li>You can desaturate by subtracting 0.5, multiplying Cw and Cm by a number between 0 and 1, and adding 0.5
331         *     afterwards,</li>
332         *     <li>you can oversaturate by subtracting 0.5, multiplying Cw and Cm by a number greater than 1, and adding 0.5
333         *     afterwards,</li>
334         *     <li>you can lighten or darken by increasing or decreasing luma,</li>
335         *     <li>and so on and so forth.</li>
336         * </ul>
337         * @param encoded a packed float
338         * @return the luma as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
339         */
340        public static float luma(final float encoded)
341        {
342                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
343//        final int bits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
344//        return (bits & 0xFF) * 0x3p-11f + (bits >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1p-9f + (bits >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1p-11f;
345        }
346
347        /**
348         * The "chroma warm" of the given packed float in YCwCm format, which when combined with chroma mild describes the
349         * shade and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . YCwCm is useful for modifications to colors:
350         * <ul>
351         *     <li>You can get a grayscale version of a color by setting Cw and Cm to 0.5,</li>
352         *     <li>You can desaturate by subtracting 0.5, multiplying Cw and Cm by a number between 0 and 1, and adding 0.5
353         *     afterwards,</li>
354         *     <li>you can oversaturate by subtracting 0.5, multiplying Cw and Cm by a number greater than 1, and adding 0.5
355         *     afterwards,</li>
356         *     <li>you can lighten or darken by increasing or decreasing luma,</li>
357         *     <li>and so on and so forth.</li>
358         * </ul>
359         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
360         * @return the chroma warm as a float from 0f to 1f
361         */
362        public static float chromaWarm(final float encoded)
363        {
364                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
365        }
366
367        /**
368         * The "chroma mild" of the given packed float in YCwCm format, which when combined with chroma warm describes the
369         * shade and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f .
370         * YCwCm is useful for modifications to colors:
371         * <ul>
372         *     <li>You can get a grayscale version of a color by setting Cw and Cm to 0.5,</li>
373         *     <li>You can desaturate by subtracting 0.5, multiplying Cw and Cm by a number between 0 and 1, and adding 0.5
374         *     afterwards,</li>
375         *     <li>you can oversaturate by subtracting 0.5, multiplying Cw and Cm by a number greater than 1, and adding 0.5
376         *     afterwards,</li>
377         *     <li>you can lighten or darken by increasing or decreasing luma,</li>
378         *     <li>and so on and so forth.</li>
379         * </ul>
380         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
381         * @return the chroma mild as a float from 0f to 1f
382         */
383        public static float chromaMild(final float encoded)
384        {
385                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
386        }
387
388        /**
389         * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, value, and
390         * opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Takes floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue,
391         * saturation, value, and opacity; these can be between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or
392         * encoded color. The float is
393         * likely to be different than the result of {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)} unless hue saturation,
394         * value, and opacity are all 0. This won't allocate any objects.
395         * <br>
396         * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
397         * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
398         * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
399         * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
400         * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
401         *
402         * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
403         * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
404         * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
405         * @param value      -1f to 1f, the value/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
406         * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
407         * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
408         */
409        public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float value, float opacity) {
410                final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
411                value = Math.min(Math.max(value + (e & 0xff) * 0x1.010102p-8f, 0f), 1f);
412                opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (e >>> 24 & 0xfe) * 0x1.020408p-8f, 0f), 1f);
413                if (value <= 0.001f)
414                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
415                final int lu = (e & 0xff);
416                final int cw = ((e >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xfe);
417                final int cm = (((e >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xfe) >> 1);
418                final float r = Math.min(Math.max(lu + (cw * 5 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
419                final float g = Math.min(Math.max(lu - (cw * 3 >> 3) + cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
420                final float b = Math.min(Math.max(lu - (cw * 3 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
421                float x, y, z, w;
422                if(g < b) {
423                        x = b;
424                        y = g;
425                        z = -1f;
426                        w = 2f / 3f;
427                }
428                else {
429                        x = g;
430                        y = b;
431                        z = 0f;
432                        w = -1f / 3f;
433                }
434                if(r < x) {
435                        z = w;
436                        w = r;
437                }
438                else {
439                        w = x;
440                        x = r;
441                }
442                final float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
443                final float light = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
444                hue += Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
445                saturation += (x - light) / (Math.min(light, 1f - light) + 1e-10f);
446                return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), light, opacity));
447        }
448
449        /**
450         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
451         * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
452         * {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
453         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
454         * white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
455         * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
456         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
457         * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
458         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
459         */
460        public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
461                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), luma = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
462                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (luma + (0xFF - luma) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
463        }
464
465        /**
466         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
467         * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
468         * {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
469         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
470         * black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
471         * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
472         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
473         * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
474         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
475         */
476        public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
477                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), luma = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
478                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (luma * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
479        }
480
481        /**
482         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a warmer color (yellow to red) by change. While change
483         * should be between 0f (returnstart as-is) and 1f (return fully warmed), start should be a packed color, as from
484         * {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
485         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
486         * a warmer color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and luma of start
487         * as-is.
488         * @see #cool(float, float) the counterpart method that cools a float color
489         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
490         * @param change how much to warm start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a warmer result
491         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a warmer color
492         */
493        public static float warm(final float start, final float change) {
494                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), warmth = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
495                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (warmth + (0xFF - warmth) * change) << 8 & 0xFF) | other);
496        }
497
498        /**
499         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a cooler color (green to blue) by change. While change
500         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as from
501         * {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
502         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
503         * a cooler color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and luma of start
504         * as-is.
505         * @see #warm(float, float) the counterpart method that warms a float color
506         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
507         * @param change how much to cool start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a cooler result
508         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a cooler color
509         */
510        public static float cool(final float start, final float change) {
511                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), warmth = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
512                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (warmth * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
513        }
514
515        /**
516         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a milder color (between green and yellow) by change. While
517         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully mild), start should be a packed color, as
518         * from {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
519         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
520         * towards a milder color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and luma of
521         * start as-is.
522         * @see #strengthen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more bold
523         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
524         * @param change how much to change start to a milder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a milder result
525         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a milder color
526         */
527        public static float weaken(final float start, final float change) {
528                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), warmth = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
529                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (warmth + (0xFF - warmth) * change) << 8 & 0xFF) | other);
530        }
531
532        /**
533         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a bolder color (between blue and red) by change. While
534         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as
535         * from {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
536         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
537         * towards a bolder color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and luma of
538         * start as-is.
539         * @see #weaken(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more mild
540         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
541         * @param change how much to change start to a bolder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a bolder result
542         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a bolder color
543         */
544        public static float strengthen(final float start, final float change) {
545                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), warmth = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
546                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (warmth * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
547        }
548
549        /**
550         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
551         * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
552         * {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
553         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
554         * transparent. This won't change the luma, chroma warm, or chroma mild of the color.
555         * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
556         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
557         * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
558         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
559         */
560        public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
561                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
562                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
563        }
564
565        /**
566         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
567         * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
568         * {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
569         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
570         * transparent. This won't change the luma, chroma warm, or chroma mild of the color.
571         * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
572         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
573         * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
574         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
575         */
576        public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
577                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
578                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
579        }
580
581        /**
582         * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
583         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
584         * from {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This only changes Cw and Cm; it leaves Y and alpha alone, unlike
585         * {@link #lessenChange(float, float)}, which usually changes Y.
586         * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
587         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
588         * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
589         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
590         */
591        public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
592                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
593                return ycwcm((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
594                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
595                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
596                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
597        }
598
599        /**
600         * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
601         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
602         * from {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This usually changes only Cw and Cm, but higher values for
603         * {@code change} can force the color out of the gamut, which this corrects using
604         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)} (and that can change Y somewhat). If the color stays in-gamut,
605         * then Y won't change; alpha never changes.
606         * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
607         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
608         * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
609         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
610         */
611        public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
612                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
613                return limitToGamut((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
614                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
615                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
616                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
617        }
618
619        /**
620         * Given a packed float YCwCm color {@code mainColor} and another YCwCm color that it should be made to contrast
621         * with, gets a packed float YCwCm color with roughly inverted luma but the same chromatic channels and opacity (Cw
622         * and Cm are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white or black). This won't ever produce black or
623         * other very dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for luma values between 0.5 and 0.55. That
624         * allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of
625         * {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the luma unchanged if the chromatic channels of the
626         * contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to do with the contrast
627         * channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar lightness values further
628         * apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its lightness difference from
629         * {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
630         * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}; this is the color that will be adjusted
631         * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
632         * @return a different packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
633         */
634        public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
635        {
636                final int bits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
637                                contrastBits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
638                                luma = (bits & 0xff),
639                                warm = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
640                                mild = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
641                                cLuma = (contrastBits & 0xff),
642                                cWarm = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
643                                cMild = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
644                if((warm - cWarm) * (warm - cWarm) + (mild - cMild) * (mild - cMild) >= 0x10000)
645                        return mainColor;
646                return ycwcm(cLuma < 128 ? luma * (0.45f / 255f) + 0.55f : 0.5f - luma * (0.45f / 255f), warm / 255f, mild / 255f, 0x1.010102p-8f * (bits >>> 24));
647        }
648
649        /**
650         * Given a packed float YCwCm color {@code mainColor} and another YCwCm color that it should be made to contrast
651         * with, gets a packed float YCwCm color with Y that should be quite different from {@code contrastingColor}'s Y,
652         * but the same chromatic channels and opacity (Cw and Cm are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white
653         * or black). This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on
654         * a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa.
655         * <br>
656         * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
657         * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant chroma. Because it
658         * averages the original Y of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to not produce harsh color changes.
659         * @param mainColor a packed YCwCm float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
660         * @param contrastingColor a packed YCwCm float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the Y of this
661         * @return a different packed YCwCm float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
662         */
663        public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
664        {
665                final int main = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor), contrast = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor);
666                return limitToGamut(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFEFFFF00) | (contrast + 128 & 0xFF) + (main & 0xFF) >>> 1));
667        }
668
669        /**
670         * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's Y and wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that
671         * with the original Y. This means light colors become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all
672         * results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
673         * @param mainColor a packed YCwCm float color
674         * @return a different packed YCwCm float color, with its Y channel changed and limited to the correct gamut
675         */
676        public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
677                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
678                return limitToGamut(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFEFFFF00) | (decoded + 128 & 0xFF) + (decoded & 0xFF) >>> 1));
679        }
680
681        /**
682         * Makes the additive YCwCm color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
683         * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
684         * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
685         * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
686         * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
687         * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
688         * @return a YCwCm float color between gray and {@code color}
689         */
690        public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
691                final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color),
692                                ys = 0x7F, cws = 0x7F, cms = 0x7F, as = 0xFE,
693                                ye = (e & 0xFF), cwe = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, cme = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, ae = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
694                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (ys + fraction * (ye - ys)) & 0xFF)
695                                | (((int) (cws + fraction * (cwe - cws)) & 0xFF) << 8)
696                                | (((int) (cms + fraction * (cme - cms)) & 0xFF) << 16)
697                                | (((int) (as + fraction * (ae - as)) & 0xFE) << 24));
698        }
699        /**
700         * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
701         * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
702         * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
703         * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
704         * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the Y, Cw, and Cm of the
705         * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
706         * isn't greater than the variance (this considers Cw and Cm extra-wide, going from -1 to 1, while I goes from 0 to
707         * 1, but only internally for measuring distance).
708         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
709         * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
710         * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
711         * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
712         */
713        public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
714                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color);
715                final float y = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
716                final float cw = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
717                final float cm = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
718                final float limit = variance * variance;
719                float dist = limit + 1f, a = 0, b = 0, c = 0;
720                while (dist > limit){
721                        a = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
722                        b = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
723                        c = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
724                        seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
725                        dist = a * a + b * b + c * c;
726                }
727                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int)(Math.min(Math.max(cm + c, -1), 1) * 127.5f + 128f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
728                                | ((int)(Math.min(Math.max(cw + b, -1), 1) * 127.5f + 128f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (int)(Math.min(Math.max(y + a, 0), 1) * 255f));
729        }
730
731        /**
732         * Returns true if the given packed float color, as YCwCm, is valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA. 
733         * @param packed a packed float color as YCwCm
734         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
735         */
736        public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
737        {
738                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed), y = (decoded & 0xff),
739                                cw = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff),
740                                cm = (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) / 2);
741                final int r = y + (cw * 5 / 8) - cm;
742                if(r < 0 || r > 255) return false;
743                final int g = y - (cw * 3 / 8) + cm;
744                if(g < 0 || g > 255) return false;
745                final int b = y - (cw * 3 / 8) - cm;
746                return (b >= 0) && (b <= 255);
747        }
748        /**
749         * Returns true if the given YCwCm values are valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA. 
750         * @param y luma channel, as a float from 0 to 1
751         * @param cw chromatic warmth channel, as a float from 0 to 1
752         * @param cm chromatic mildness channel, as a float from 0 to 1
753         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
754         */
755        public static boolean inGamut(float y, float cw, float cm)
756        {
757                final int yi = (int)(y * 255.999f), cwi = (int) ((cw - 0.5f) * 511.999f), cmi = (int) ((cm - 0.5f) * 255.999f);
758                final int r = yi + (cwi * 5 / 8) - cmi;
759                if(r < 0 || r > 255) return false;
760                final int g = yi - (cwi * 3 / 8) + cmi;
761                if(g < 0 || g > 255) return false;
762                final int b = yi - (cwi * 3 / 8) - cmi;
763                return (b >= 0) && (b <= 255);
764        }
765
766        /**
767         * Iteratively checks whether the given YCwCm color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if
768         * it isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut.
769         * @param packed a packed float color in YCwCm format; often this color is not in-gamut
770         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given YCwCm color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
771         * @see #inGamut(float) You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
772         */
773        public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
774                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
775                final float y = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
776                final float cw = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
777                final float cm = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 255f;
778                float y2 = y, cw2 = cw, cm2 = cm;
779                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
780                        final float r = y2 + 0.625f * cw2 - cm2;
781                        final float g = y2 - 0.375f * cw2 + cm2;
782                        final float b = y2 - 0.375f * cw2 - cm2;
783                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
784                                break;
785                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
786                        y2 = MathTools.lerp(0.5f, y, progress);
787                        cw2 = MathTools.lerp(0, cw, progress);
788                        cm2 = MathTools.lerp(0, cm, progress);
789                }
790                return ycwcm(y2, cw2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, cm2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
791        }
792
793        /**
794         * Iteratively checks whether the given YCwCm color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if
795         * it isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. This always produces an opaque color.
796         * @param y luma component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
797         * @param cw chromatic warmth component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
798         * @param cm chromatic mildness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
799         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given YCwCm color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
800         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
801         */
802        public static float limitToGamut(float y, float cw, float cm) {
803                return limitToGamut(y, cw, cm, 1f);
804        }
805
806        /**
807         * Iteratively checks whether the given YCwCm color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if
808         * it isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut.
809         * @param y luma component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
810         * @param cw chromatic warmth component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
811         * @param cm chromatic mildness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
812         * @param a alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
813         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given YCwCm color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
814         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
815         */
816        public static float limitToGamut(float y, float cw, float cm, float a)
817        {
818                float y2 = y = Math.min(Math.max(y, 0f), 1f);
819                float cw2 = cw = Math.min(Math.max((cw - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f), 1f);
820                float cm2 = cm = Math.min(Math.max((cm - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f), 1f);
821                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
822                        final float r = y2 + 0.625f * cw2 - cm2;
823                        final float g = y2 - 0.375f * cw2 + cm2;
824                        final float b = y2 - 0.375f * cw2 - cm2;
825                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
826                                break;
827                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
828                        y2 = MathTools.lerp(0.5f, y, progress);
829                        cw2 = MathTools.lerp(0, cw, progress);
830                        cm2 = MathTools.lerp(0, cm, progress);
831                }
832                return ycwcm(y2, cw2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, cm2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, Math.min(Math.max(a, 0f), 1f));
833        }
834
835
836
837        /**
838         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut and should be uniformly distributed.
839         * @param random a Random object (or preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.github.tommyettinger.ds.support.LaserRandom})
840         * @return a random opaque packed float color that is always in-gamut
841         */
842        public static float randomColor(Random random) {
843                final float yr = +0.375f, wr = +0.5f, mr = +0.0f;
844                final float yg = +0.500f, wg = +0.0f, mg = +0.5f;
845                final float yb = +0.125f, wb = -0.5f, mb = -0.5f;
846                final float r = random.nextFloat(), g = random.nextFloat(), b = random.nextFloat();
847                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(0xFE000000
848                                | ((int) ((mr * r + mg * g + mb * b) * 128f + 128f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
849                                | ((int) ((wr * r + wg * g + wb * b) * 128f + 128f) << 8 & 0xFF00)
850                                | ((int) ((yr * r + yg * g + yb * b) * 256f) & 0xFF));
851        }
852
853}
